abstract.text: An XML document as internalized into a logical tree structure.

inlineContent.text: An
object can have multiple child nodes but only one element, the root element. Any other node must be a
object representing a comment or a processing instruction. If you attempt to add any other kind of child node to an
object, such as an attribute, namespace, another document object, or an element other than the root,
raises an exception. If you add a valid child node and that object already has a parent,
raises an exception. An
object may also have document-global attributes, such as XML version, character encoding, referenced DTD, and MIME type.
The initializers of the
class read an external source of XML, whether it be a local file or remote website, parse it, and process it into the tree representation. You can also construct an

programmatically. There are accessor methods for getting and setting document attributes, methods for transforming documents using XSLT, a method for dynamically validating a document, and methods for printing out the content of an
as XML, XHTML, HTML, or plain text.
The
class is thread-safe as long as any given instance is used only in one thread.
To subclass
you need to override the primary initializer,
, and the methods listed below. In most cases, you need only invoke the superclass implementation, adding any subclass-specific code before or after the invocation, as necessary.
By default
implements the
method to perform a deep comparison: two

objects are not considered equal unless they have the same name, same child nodes, same attributes, and so on. The comparison does not consider the parent node (and hence the node’s location). If you want a different standard of comparison, override
Because of the architecture and data model of NSXML, when it parses and processes a source of XML it cannot know about your subclass unless you override the class method
to return your custom class in place of an
class. If your custom class has no direct
counterpart—for example, it is a subclass of
that represents CDATA sections—then you can walk the tree after it has been created and insert the new node where appropriate.

abstract.text: An XML document as internalized into a logical tree structure.
Sets the kind of output content for the receiver.
Sets the child nodes of the receiver.
Validates the document against the governing schema and returns whether the document conforms to the schema.
Returns the MIME type for the receiver.
Returns an
object initialized with a single child, the root element.
Sets the version of the receiver’s XML.
Overridden by subclasses to substitute a custom class for an NSXML class that the parser uses to create node instances.
Applies the XSLT pattern rules and templates (specified as a string) to the receiver and returns a document object containing transformed XML or HTML markup.
Removes the child node of the receiver located at a specified position in its array of children.
Applies the XSLT pattern rules and templates located at a specified URL to the receiver and returns a document object containing transformed XML markup or an
object containing plain text, RTF text, and so on.
Sets the character encoding of the receiver to
Returns the XML string representation of the receiver—that is, the entire document—encapsulated in a data object.
Returns the root element of the receiver.
Returns the XML string representation of the receiver—that is, the entire document—encapsulated in a data object.
Initializes and returns an
object created from an
object.
Sets a Boolean value that specifies whether the receiver represents a standalone XML document.
Inserts a node object at specified position in the receiver’s array of children.
Set the root element of the receiver.
Inserts an array of children at a specified position in the receiver’s array of children.
Adds a child node after the last of the receiver’s existing children.
Applies the XSLT pattern rules and templates (specified as a data object) to the receiver and returns a document object containing transformed XML or HTML markup.
Initializes and returns an
object created from a string containing XML markup text.
Replaces the child node of the receiver located at a specified position in its array of children with another node.
Initializes and returns an NSXMLDocument object created from the XML or HTML contents of a URL-referenced source
Returns an
object representing the internal DTD associated with the receiver.
Sets the internal DTD to be associated with the receiver.
Returns whether the receiver represents a standalone XML document—that is, one without an external DTD.
Sets the MIME type of the receiver.
Returns the URI identifying the source of this document.
Sets the URI identifying the source of this document.
Define document types.
Input and output options specifically intended for
objects.
Type used to define the kind of document content.
A representation of a Document Type Definition.
A representation of element, attribute-list, entity, and notation declarations in a Document Type Definition.
The element nodes in an XML tree structure.
The nodes in the abstract, logical tree structure that represents an XML document.

topicSections.title: Writing a Document as XML Data
